   CT torso:
   1. No CT evidence of disseminated fungal infection. Large amount of
   ascites
   within the abdomen and pelvis. Diffuse bowel wall thickening which may
   be
   related to third spacing. However, given history of C. difficile
   infection,
   bowel wall thickening of the colon could also represent colitis.
   2. Continued hypoenhancement of the kidneys bilaterally, unchanged from
   [**4-5**], [**2168**], again concerning for cortical necrosis.
   3. Peripheral nonenhancement of the spleen, unchanged, consistent with
   splenic infarction.
   4. Central venous line ends within the upper inferior vena cava,
   unchanged.
   5. Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.
   6. Diffuse anasarca, worsening.
   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Mental
   status improved today.
   - Trial SBT again today for 30-60min to see whether can trial
   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21
   ICU Care

   3. Peripheral nonenhancement of the spleen, unchanged, consistent with
   splenic infarction.
   4. Central venous line ends within the upper inferior vena cava,
   unchanged.
   5. Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.
   6. Diffuse anasarca, worsening.
   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff

   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .

   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .

   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her

   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .

   - continue local care, wound vac

   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt

   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD

   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and autoimmune cholangiopathy. She was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, candidemia, and sepsis. She has a history of C. difficile colitis and has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and micafungin. She has also had a recent episode of peritonitis and has been treated with peritoneal dialysis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with a temperature of 36.6C (97.8F), a heart rate of 68 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 112/49 mmHg. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and her respiratory status is stable. She has a WBC count of 23.8 x 10^9/L and a platelet count of 301 x 10^9/L.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and lactate dehydrogenase, indicating kidney and liver dysfunction. Her liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin.

The patient's radiology results show evidence of disseminated fungal infection, with multiple nodules and masses in the lungs, liver, and spleen. There is also evidence of peritonitis and ascites.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely caused by a combination of factors, including her underlying medical conditions, her recent antibiotic use, and her Candida infection.
2. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia is likely caused by her Candida infection and may be related to her recent antibiotic use.
3. Peritonitis: The patient's peritonitis is likely caused by her recent episode of peritonitis and may be related to her underlying medical conditions.
4. Ascites: The patient's ascites is likely caused by her liver dysfunction and may be related to her underlying medical conditions.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely caused by her underlying medical conditions, including her ESRD, and may be related to her recent antibiotic use.
6. Liver failure: The patient's liver failure is likely caused by her underlying medical conditions, including her autoimmune cholangiopathy, and may be related to her recent antibiotic use.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely caused by her underlying medical conditions, including her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and may be related to her recent antibiotic use.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability is likely caused by her underlying medical conditions, including her hypertension and her recent antibiotic use.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis and candidemia with antibiotics and antifungal medications.
3. Continue to manage the patient's ascites and peritonitis with diuretics and antibiotics.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal and liver function and adjust her medications accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her mechanical ventilation settings as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability and adjust her medications accordingly.
7. Consider consulting with a nephrologist or a gastroenterologist to further evaluate the patient's underlying medical conditions and develop a treatment plan.
8. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist to further evaluate the patient's respiratory status and develop a treatment plan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with recent sepsis, C. diff, and multiple abdominal infections, who is currently in the ICU. The patient's altered mental status is a concern.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis is not yet fully controlled, and there is a risk of organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or cardiovascular instability.
2. C. diff colitis: The patient's C. diff infection may not be fully treated, and there is a risk of recurrent or relapsing infection.
3. Abdominal infections: The patient's multiple abdominal infections may not be fully treated, and there is a risk of recurrent or relapsing infection.
4. Wound complications: The patient's wound is not yet fully healed, and there is a risk of wound complications, such as infection, dehiscence, or delayed healing.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and there is a risk of respiratory failure, particularly given her history of sepsis and abdominal infections.
6. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a risk of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status is compromised, and there is a risk of cardiovascular instability, particularly given her history of sepsis and abdominal infections.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and there is a risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, encephalopathy, or stroke.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to detect any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent or manage them.

   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the MICU with altered
   mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Her PICC  & HD now pulled out and new IJ
   placed [**4-14**]. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate. Left thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from
   thigh NGTD.  She had no more fevers overnight but  is still very
   dependent on pressors. WBC still elevated at 23 ( has been ranging
   22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage negative for SBP and no fungus
   growing to date.  She has clean eye exam with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome for now pending speciation
   and sensitivities.
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited for fresh access / all old
   lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u final CT torso final read
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean  sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Now had 2L
   taken off abd yesterday and pleural effusions better.
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Normal cortisol levels this morning. CVP 12 now.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed yesterday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and autoimmune cholangiopathy. She was recently hospitalized for a prolonged period due to a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube-related abdominal abscess, which required debridement, and was also diagnosed with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia.

The patient was transferred back to the intensive care unit (ICU) with altered mental status and was found to have candidemia. The likely source of the candidemia is a line-related infection, possibly related to the TPN. The patient has had prior C. glabrata line infections treated with fluconazole.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Candidemia: The patient has candidemia, which is likely line-related, and is being treated with micafungin and Ambisome.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which is likely disseminated fungal infection, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
3. Leukocytosis and fever: The patient has leukocytosis and fever, which are likely related to the sepsis and candidemia.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely related to the sepsis, candidemia, and potential seizure activity.
5. Hypoxia: The patient is hypoxic, which is likely related to fluid overload and altered mental status.
6. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which is likely related to sepsis and fluid overload.
7. Abdominal wound: The patient has an abdominal wound, which is being managed with a wound vacuum.
8. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient has portal venous and RIJ clots, which are being managed with anticoagulation therapy.
9. Hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has hepatitis B and autoimmune cholangiopathy, which are being managed with antiviral therapy and immunosuppressive therapy.
10. ESRD on HD: The patient has ESRD on HD, which is being managed with HD therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's candidemia can lead to disseminated fungal infection, which can be life-threatening.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can lead to organ failure, including respiratory, cardiac, and renal failure.
3. Leukopenia: The patient's leukocytosis can lead to leukopenia, which can increase the risk of infection.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to organ failure, including cardiac, renal, and cerebral failure.
5. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal wound can lead to abdominal compartment syndrome, which can be life-threatening.
6. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots can lead to thrombosis, which can be life-threatening.
7. Hepatitis B and autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient's hepatitis B and autoimmune cholangiopathy can lead to liver failure, which can be life-threatening.
8. ESRD on HD: The patient's ESRD on HD can lead to chronic kidney disease, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease and mortality.

Based on the patient's current condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue antifungal therapy with micafungin and Ambisome.
2. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis.
3. Manage the patient's altered mental status with sedation and neuromuscular blockade as needed.
4. Manage the patient's hypoxia with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as needed.
5. Manage the patient's hypotension with vasopressors and fluid therapy as needed.
6. Manage the patient's abdominal wound with wound care and wound vacuum therapy.
7. Manage the patient's portal venous and RIJ clots with anticoagulation therapy.
8. Manage the patient's hepatitis B and autoimmune cholangiopathy with antiviral therapy and immunosuppressive therapy.
9. Manage the patient's ESRD on HD with HD therapy and close monitoring of renal function.
10. Monitor the patient's condition closely for any signs of deterioration or complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess. She has been diagnosed with candidemia and sepsis, likely related to a line infection. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection, and her mental status has been altered.

The patient has a history of C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole, and it is possible that she has seeded bone, heart, or venous clots or abscesses. The patient's WBC count is slightly down from 26 to 22 range, and her fevers have continued overnight.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Candidemia and sepsis: The patient has a likely line-related infection, and her blood cultures have grown Candida. She is being treated with micafungin, and daily cultures are being performed.
2. Leukocytosis and fever: The patient has a likely disseminated fungal infection, and her WBC count is slightly down from 26 to 22 range.
3. Altered mental status: The patient has been intubated for airway protection, and her mental status has been altered. She may have had a seizure, and her EEG showed no active seizures.
4. Hypoxia: The patient is intubated for airway protection, and her oxygenation has improved today. However, she is still tachypneic on PSV, and it is suspected that this is related to fluid overload or altered mental status.
5. Hypotension: The patient has suspected sepsis, and her propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume overloaded, and her CVP is 12.
6. Abdominal wound: The patient's wound vac was changed yesterday, and her ABD CT is unchanged.
7. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient is holding heparin in anticipation of a new line.
8. HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient is being treated with entecavir, tenofovir, and ursodiol.
9. ESRD on HD: The patient's HD line was removed, and she is being sent for culture. Per renal, there is no urgent need for HD today, but she may need CVVH due to her pressor requirement.
10. DM: The patient is being treated with insulin, and her Hct is stable.
11. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, and she is being maintained on active T+S and transfused for Hct>21.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her multiple medical complications. She will likely require further surgical interventions, including removal of the left IJ and placement of a new HD line. Her ID recs are pending, and her neuro c/s is being considered. Her liver recs are also appreciated.

   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the MICU with altered
   mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Her PICC  & HD now pulled out and new IJ
   placed [**4-14**]. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate. Left thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from
   thigh NGTD. . Still fevers overnight to 101F range. Weaned pressors
   overnight but now back  on due to overnight SBPs dropping to 70s.  WBC
   slightly down from 26 to 22 range. Ascites drainage negative for SBP
   and no fungus growing to date.
   .
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities.
   - daily cultures for now
   - stop TPN for now
   - holding off on Ambisome for now
   - may need to have left IJ removed  that was placed [**4-14**] given positive
   cultures on that date
   - consider femoral line placement this afternoon vs. new HD line ( will
   d/w renal)
   - will likely need new A-line as well
   - will need eye exam / ophthalmology consult today
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable

   - daily blood cultures, f/u pending micro from ascites & pleural tap as
   well
   - f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBC slight drop to 22 today, fevers
   continued to 101F overnight. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  Now has left
   IJs in place still.
   - trending fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - formal eye exam/ophthalmology consult as above
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C. diff diagnosis
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.

   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Now had 2L

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and recent prolonged hospitalization for a perforated gastric ulcer (PEG) with abdominal abscess and gram-negative bacteremia. She was recently transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status, candidemia, and likely line-related sepsis. She has a history of C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 37.1C, Tcurrent 36.6C, HR 68 bpm, BP 112/49 mmHg, RR 27 inspirations per minute, SpO2 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 16 mmHg, MAP 70 mmHg
* Fluid balance: Total In 3,347 mL, Total Out 70 mL, Fluid Balance 3,277 mL
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 40%
* Laboratory results: WBC 22.2 x 10^9/L, Hct 26.7%, Plt 301 x 10^9/L, Cr 3.2 mg/dL, TropT 0.23 ng/mL, Glucose 101 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has candidemia and likely line-related sepsis, which may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's WBC count is slightly down, but she still has a high fever, which may indicate a disseminated fungal infection.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, which may be a sign of an underlying infection or inflammation.
4. Hypoxia: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, which may be related to fluid overload or sepsis.
5. Hypotension: The patient's BP is dependent on pressors, which may indicate sepsis or fluid overload.
6. Abdominal wound: The patient has an abdominal wound that is being managed with a wound vac, but may require further surgical intervention.
7. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient has a history of portal venous and RIJ clots, which may be related to her ESRD and sepsis.
8. Hepatitis B: The patient has HBV, which may be related to her ESRD and sepsis.
9. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has a history of autoimmune cholangiopathy, which may be related to her HBV and ESRD.
10. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, but may require transfusion if it falls below 21%.

Plan:

1. Continue micafungin and daily cultures for now.
2. Stop TPN for now.
3. Holding off on Ambisome for now.
4. May need to remove left IJ that was placed on 4/14 given positive cultures.
5. Consider femoral line placement this afternoon vs. new HD line.
6. Will likely need new A-line as well.
7. Will need eye exam/ophthalmology consult today.
8. Continue to follow synthetic function tests.
9. Continue entecavir and tenofovir.
10. Continue ursodiol.
11. Wean pressors as tolerated.
12. Trend lactate.
13. Continue local care, wound vac.
14. Hold heparin in anticipation of new line.
15. Continue insulin.
16. Follow lytes daily.
17. Maintain active T+S and transfuse for Hct > 21.
18. Follow up with renal, liver, and infectious disease teams as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement. She was transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status and candidemia. She has a history of C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d and has been off micafungin on the floor, which correlates with positive blood cultures. She has a left thigh fluid collection previously drained with cultures from the thigh NGTD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Candidemia/Septicemia: She has candidemia and septicemia, likely related to a line infection, and is being treated with micafungin.
* Leukocytosis and Fever: She has leukocytosis and fever, likely related to disseminated fungal infection, and is being treated with cefepime, amikacin, and IV vanco.
* Altered Mental Status: She has altered mental status, which is being treated with sedation and antibiotics.
* Hypoxia: She is intubated for airway protection and is being treated with oxygen therapy.
* Hypotension: She has hypotension, likely related to sepsis, and is being treated with pressors.
* Abdominal Wound: She has an abdominal wound that is being treated with local care and wound vac.
* Portal Venous and RIJ Clots: She has portal venous and RIJ clots, which are being treated with heparin.
* HepB, Autoimmune Cholangiopathy: She has HepB and autoimmune cholangiopathy, which is being treated with entecavir, tenofovir, and ursodiol.
* ESRD on HD: She has ESRD on HD, which is being managed with HD and CVVH.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to her candidemia and septicemia.
* Disseminated Fungal Infection: The patient is at risk of developing a disseminated fungal infection due to her candidemia.
* Line-Related Complications: The patient is at risk of developing line-related complications, such as infection, thrombosis, and embolism.
* Abdominal Complications: The patient is at risk of developing abdominal complications, such as perforation, abscess, and bleeding.
* Cardiovascular Complications: The patient is at risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
* Neurological Complications: The patient is at risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures, encephalopathy, and stroke.
* Renal Complications: The patient is at risk of developing renal complications, such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.

Plan:

* Continue treatment with micafungin and other antibiotics as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's condition closely for signs of sepsis, disseminated fungal infection, and line-related complications.
* Consider surgical intervention for abdominal complications.
* Monitor the patient's cardiovascular and neurological status closely and provide supportive care as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's renal function closely and provide supportive care as necessary.
* Consider CVVH for fluid removal and electrolyte management.
* Continue to follow the patient's laboratory results and adjust treatment as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the MICU with altered
   mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Her PICC  & HD now pulled out and new IJ
   placed [**4-14**]. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate. Left thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from
   thigh NGTD. . Still fevers overnight to 101F range. Weaned pressors
   overnight but now back  on due to overnight SBPs dropping to 70s.  WBC
   slightly down from 26 to 22 range. Ascites drainage negative for SBP
   and no fungus growing to date.
   .
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities.
   - daily cultures for now
   - stop TPN for now
   - holding off on Ambisome for now
   - may need to have left IJ removed  that was placed [**4-14**] given positive
   cultures on that date
   - consider femoral line placement this afternoon vs. new HD line ( will
   d/w renal)
   - will likely need new A-line as well
   - will need eye exam / ophthalmology consult today
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u final CT torso final read
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan
   - daily blood cultures, f/u pending micro from ascites & pleural tap as
   well
   - f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBC slight drop to 22 today, fevers
   continued to 101F overnight. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  Now has left
   IJs in place still.
   - trending fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - formal eye exam/ophthalmology consult as above
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C. diff diagnosis
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean  sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Now had 2L
   taken off abd yesterday and pleural effusions better.
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Normal cortisol levels this morning. CVP 12 now.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed yesterday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, HBV, and a recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement. She was transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status and candidemia.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Candidemia: The patient has candidemia, which is likely line-related in the setting of TPN. She had a prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole for 23 days.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which is likely caused by the candidemia.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which is likely caused by the sepsis.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely caused by the sepsis and candidemia.
5. Hypoxia: The patient has hypoxia, which is likely caused by the sepsis and candidemia.
6. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which is likely caused by the sepsis and candidemia.
7. Abdominal wound: The patient has an abdominal wound that requires wound care and may require surgery.
8. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient has portal venous and RIJ clots, which may require anticoagulation therapy.
9. Hepatitis B: The patient has hepatitis B, which requires ongoing treatment with entecavir and tenofovir.
10. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has autoimmune cholangiopathy, which requires ongoing treatment with ursodiol.
11. DM: The patient has DM, which requires ongoing treatment with insulin.
12. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which requires ongoing treatment with blood transfusions.

The patient's medical conditions and complications require ongoing management and treatment, including:

1. Antibiotic therapy: The patient requires ongoing antibiotic therapy to treat the candidemia and sepsis.
2. Antifungal therapy: The patient requires ongoing antifungal therapy to treat the candidemia.
3. Wound care: The patient requires ongoing wound care to manage the abdominal wound.
4. Anticoagulation therapy: The patient may require anticoagulation therapy to prevent the formation of new clots.
5. Liver function tests: The patient requires ongoing liver function tests to monitor the progression of her autoimmune cholangiopathy.
6. Renal function tests: The patient requires ongoing renal function tests to monitor the progression of her ESRD.
7. Blood transfusions: The patient may require ongoing blood transfusions to manage her anemia.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including candidemia, sepsis, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hypoxia, hypotension, abdominal wound, portal venous and RIJ clots, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, DM, and anemia. The patient requires ongoing management and treatment to address these complications and prevent further complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 48-year-old male with ESRD and HBV cirrhosis who has been in the ICU for an extended period. He has a prolonged course after a recent complicated abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia, and now has fungemia. The patient is currently on micafungin and ambisome per ID, and a fungal culture suggests Candida albicans. He is also receiving empiric antibacterial therapy.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Sepsis: The patient's fungemia and prolonged course in the ICU make him susceptible to sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is overventilating on PSV 12/5. If not managed properly, this can lead to respiratory failure and ARDS.
3. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection: The patient is receiving empiric antibacterial therapy, which may not be effective against C. diff. If not managed properly, C. diff can lead to severe diarrhea, colitis, and even death.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to toxic metabolic encephalopathy, which can lead to permanent brain damage or death if not managed properly.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is at risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
6. Portal Vein Thrombosis and Renal IJ Thrombosis: The patient is at risk for further thrombotic complications, which can lead to organ failure and death.
7. Autoimmune Cholangiopathy: The patient's autoimmune cholangiopathy may lead to chronic liver disease and potentially liver failure if not managed properly.
8. Fungal Colonization of Intravascular Clots: The patient's fungemia and prolonged course in the ICU make him susceptible to fungal colonization of intravascular clots, which can lead to further sepsis and organ failure.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes in his condition.
2. Adjust his antibacterial and antifungal therapy as necessary to ensure effective treatment of his infections.
3. Continue to manage his respiratory status closely to prevent respiratory failure.
4. Consider adding C. diff therapy to his regimen if his stool cultures become positive.
5. Monitor his mental status closely and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent further deterioration.
6. Consider adding a renal protective agent to his regimen to prevent further kidney damage.
7. Monitor his portal vein thrombosis and renal IJ thrombosis closely and consider adding anticoagulation therapy if necessary.
8. Consider adding a liver protective agent to his regimen to prevent further liver damage.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and hepatitis B cirrhosis who has had a prolonged hospital course after a complicated abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia. He has now developed fungemia and is being treated with micafungin and ambisome.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his fungemia and polymicrobial bacteremia. He is already receiving empiric antibiotics, but the ID team will need to tailor the regimen based on the results of the fungal culture.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is overventilating on PSV 12/5, and his oxygenation is adequate. He will need to be weaned off the ventilator as soon as possible.
3. Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection: The patient has a high risk of developing C. diff infection due to his prolonged hospital stay and antibiotic use. He is currently receiving vancomycin and metronidazole, but will likely require a prolonged course of treatment.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to toxic metabolic encephalopathy. He will need to be closely monitored for signs of worsening encephalopathy, and his medications will need to be adjusted accordingly.
5. Renal failure: The patient is currently on hemodialysis (HD) holiday, but will eventually require renal replacement therapy (RRT) due to his ESRD and ongoing fluid losses.
6. Portal vein thrombosis: The patient has a history of portal vein thrombosis and will need to be monitored closely for signs of recurrence.
7. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has completed a steroid taper for autoimmune cholangiopathy, but will need to be closely monitored for signs of relapse.

The patient is at high risk for several medical complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, C. diff infection, altered mental status, renal failure, portal vein thrombosis, and autoimmune cholangiopathy. He will require close monitoring and management to prevent these complications and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a [age]-year-old with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, hypotension, chronic renal failure, and acute respiratory failure. The patient was successfully extubated on 4/17 and is currently on invasive ventilation with a nasal cannula and CPAP/PSV mode. The patient requires hemodialysis and will need a temporary hemodialysis line placed tomorrow. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/49 mmHg. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 27.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 6.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 415 K/uL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure may worsen, requiring dialysis or renal replacement therapy.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock, requiring vasopressors and fluid resuscitation.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension may worsen, requiring vasopressors and fluid resuscitation.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's acute respiratory failure and sepsis may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's acute respiratory failure and sepsis may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
7. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's chronic renal failure may increase the risk of hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding or hematuria.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, renal, and cardiovascular status to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative

   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   - Patient with positive BCx [**4-11**], [**4-13**], [**4-14**] with [**Female First Name (un) **] albicans
   likely in setting of TPN while off micafungin on floor. new A-line and
   right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all old lines
   removed
   Patient
s abx narrowed yesterday to remain only on micafungin, and
   cdiff coverage (PO vanc/flagyl). WBC continues to trend upwards without
   fever
 other site cultures have been negative (pleural fluid, left
   thigh fluid collection, peritoneal tap). Other site of seeding could be
   her valve with plan for TEE this week.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs regarding send out fungal sensitivities
   - Continue micafungin (restarted [**4-14**]) and cdiff tx with PO vanc
   (day#1=[**4-1**]) and flagyl (day #1=[**4-5**])
   - f/u cultures
   - holding all TPN for now
   - plan for TEE tomorrow
 call TEE fellow to confirm today
   .
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. No more fevers, but WBC
   trending upwards. Other sites to evaluate include abdominal wound and
   heart valves. Still septic physiology requiring low dose pressors.
   - ID following -
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - TEE to r/o vegetations
   - will hold off on repeat IR drainage of thigh fluid collections
   - continue CIS

   well at 2L .  Initial SOB may have been fluid related or related to

   improved today.
   - s/p extubation and doing well on NC at 2L , wean as tolerates
   - d/c Fentanyl today to limit sedation  ( Tylenol PRN)
   - favor additional volume removal, will get CVVH today.
   .
   # Altered mental status: Extubated yesterday and maintaining airway
   since. Mental status improved, but patient still lethargic with low
   energy. No evidence of seizures s/p extubation. Would be careful with
   narcotic medications as could have played role in lathergy/transfer
   back to MICU. Also may have element of uremia and hepatic related
   encephalopathy.
   -  continue to hold narcotics for now
   - getting CVVH , will help uremia effects
   -  treating infections as above
   - start lactulose today, follow up liver recs
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] septic etiology. She appears
   intravascularly volume overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low
   dose Levophed but unable to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed
   - monitor closely in setting of upcoming dialysis / CVVH today
   - Treating infection as above

   Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Plan for CVVH/HD today with
   placement of temp HD catheter today. Heparin on hold this AM in
   preparation
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Plan for temp line placement and CVVH/HD today
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   Nutrition will be issue for the patient. Had abdominal infection s/p
   PEG placement, now with candidemia likely in setting of TPN.
   - Nutrition:  Dophoff placement for now vs re-evaluate ability to take
   POs (as will likely will not be enough intake & very  poor gag reflex
   now)
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac in place
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
 holding for AM for HD catheter placement but will
   resume after procedure later today
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI until better
   intake w/Dobhoff feeds
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, C. difficile colitis, and a history of prolonged hospitalization, PEG placement, and abdominal abscess. She was recently readmitted with new candidemia and C. difficile colitis. The patient's condition is complicated by ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prednisone taper for autoimmune cholangiopathy. She has ongoing infections, including disseminated fungal infection, and is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fungemia sepsis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to multi-organ failure, shock, and death.
2. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile colitis may progress, leading to further complications such as toxic megacolon, perforation, and sepsis.
3. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia may lead to further dissemination of the fungus, causing complications such as endocarditis, meningitis, and osteomyelitis.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen, leading to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause confusion, altered mental status, and seizures.
5. Uremic complications: The patient's ESRD on HD may lead to uremic complications such as seizures, encephalopathy, and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and inability to take PO medications may lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients, exacerbating her underlying conditions.
7. Wound complications: The patient's abdominal wound may become infected or develop complications such as dehiscence, leading to further morbidity and mortality.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's septic physiology and hypotension may lead to cardiovascular complications such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
9. Respiratory complications: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antifungal therapy with micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vanc and flagyl.
2. Perform a TEE to rule out fungal vegetations on the heart valves.
3. Hold all TPN until further evaluation and treatment of the patient's infections.
4. Wean the patient off pressors as tolerated and monitor for signs of sepsis.
5. Continue CVVH/HD with placement of a temporary HD catheter.
6. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider Dobhoff placement for nutrition.
7. Continue to follow synthetic function tests and liver recs.
8. Manage the patient's abdominal wound with local care and wound vac.
9. Resume heparin gtt after the procedure today.
10. Continue insulin and Humalog SSI for DM management.
11. Maintain active T+S and transfuse for Hct>21.
12. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider lactulose for hepatic encephalopathy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, hypotension, chronic renal failure, and acute respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 110/49 mmHg. The patient is receiving invasive ventilation, with a FiO2 of 40% and a PIP of 18 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of chronic kidney disease, with a creatinine level of 3.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 27.2 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are within normal limits, with a total bilirubin level of 1.6 mg/dL and an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 36 IU/L.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.42, a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 29 mmHg, and a partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 124 mmHg.

The patient's blood products show a total output of 1,376 mL, with an input of 921 mL and an output of 600 mL. The patient's urine output is 600 mL, with a specific gravity of 1.016.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's critical condition, with no assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic status.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury or respiratory failure.
2. Chronic kidney disease progression, leading to end-stage renal disease.
3. Respiratory failure, potentially requiring mechanical ventilation.
4. Hypotension, potentially requiring vasopressor support.
5. Infection, potentially leading to septic shock or multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Nutritional deficiencies, potentially leading to malnutrition or impaired wound healing.
7. Glycemic control issues, potentially leading to hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend continued close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status. The patient's medication regimen should be reviewed and adjusted as necessary to optimize glycemic control, pain management, and infection prevention. Additionally, the patient's nutritional needs should be assessed and addressed to prevent malnutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, ESRD on HD, HBV, and a history of prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement and abdominal abscess requiring debridement. The patient has been readmitted with C. difficile colitis and new candidemia with Candida albicans.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.3C, HR 67 bpm, BP 110/49 mmHg, RR 27 insp/min, SpO2 96%
* Respiratory support: Nasal cannula with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 40%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Norepinephrine infusion at 0.05 mcg/kg/min
* Fluid balance: Total fluid input 1,376 mL, total fluid output 776 mL, with a net fluid balance of -507 mL
* Renal function: Hemodialysis required, with plans for temporary HD catheter placement today
* Hepatic function: Hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and liver dysfunction
* Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed on Friday, with plans for plastic surgery follow-up
* Coagulation: On heparin gtt, holding for HD line placement at 6 am tomorrow
* Blood products: 600 mL blood products transfused, with plans for additional transfusions as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Disseminated fungal infection with Candida albicans, potentially leading to septic shock and organ failure
* C. difficile colitis, which can worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of complications
* Hypotension, which may require further treatment and monitoring
* Hypoxia, which may require adjustments to respiratory support and oxygen therapy
* Altered mental status, which may require further evaluation and treatment
* ESRD on HD, which may require further adjustments to dialysis and fluid management
* Hepatic dysfunction, which may require further evaluation and treatment
* Abdominal wound infection, which may require further treatment and monitoring
* Coagulation disorders, which may require further evaluation and treatment

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vanc and flagyl
* Monitoring for fungal sensitivities and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Performing a TEE to rule out valve vegetations
* Continuing to hold TPN for now
* Planning for CVVH/HD today with placement of temporary HD catheter
* Holding heparin gtt until 6 am tomorrow, then resuming
* Continuing entecavir and tenofovir for HBV treatment
* Continuing ursodiol for liver dysfunction
* Following synthetic function tests for liver function
* Continuing local care for the abdominal wound
* Resuming heparin gtt after the procedure tomorrow

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, C. difficile colitis, and ESRD on HD. She has been readmitted to the ICU after being discharged from the hospital with a prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement and abdominal abscess debridement. The patient has been treated with micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl. She has been extubated and is currently on low-dose pressors for septic physiology. The patient has also been diagnosed with candidemia, and fungal sensitivities are pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's WBC is trending upwards, and she has been diagnosed with candidemia. This could indicate a disseminated fungal infection, which could lead to further complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology is requiring low-dose pressors, and she has a high risk of developing septic shock.
3. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia could lead to further complications, such as endocarditis or disseminated candidiasis.
4. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile colitis could lead to further complications, such as toxic megacolon or perforation.
5. ESRD on HD: The patient's ESRD on HD could lead to further complications, such as dialysis-related complications or electrolyte imbalances.
6. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia could lead to further complications, such as respiratory failure or pneumonia.
7. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status could lead to further complications, such as delirium or seizures.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could lead to further complications, such as shock or cardiac arrest.
9. Abdominal wound: The patient's abdominal wound could lead to further complications, such as infection or dehiscence.
10. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots could lead to further complications, such as thrombosis or embolism.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's fungal sensitivities and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Continue to treat the patient's C. difficile colitis with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
3. Monitor the patient's septic physiology and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Consider performing a TEE to rule out vegetations.
5. Continue to hold narcotics and monitor the patient's mental status.
6. Wean pressors as tolerated and monitor the patient's blood pressure.
7. Consider CVVH/HD for the patient's ESRD on HD.
8. Monitor the patient's abdominal wound and consider further surgical intervention.
9. Monitor the patient's portal venous and RIJ clots and consider further treatment.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis and candidemia: The patient has a positive BCx culture for Candida albicans, which is a risk factor for sepsis and candidemia. The patient's WBC count is trending upwards, and the patient is still septic, which may lead to further complications.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, which may be a sign of an underlying infection or inflammation.
3. Hypoxia: The patient is intubated and has been experiencing tachypnea, which may be related to fluid overload or altered mental status. The patient's oxygenation is improving, but they may still be at risk for respiratory failure.
4. Altered mental status: The patient is lethargic and has low energy, which may be related to infection, sepsis, or medication side effects. The patient's mental status has improved, but they are still at risk for further decline.
5. Hypotension: The patient has been requiring low-dose pressors to maintain blood pressure, which may indicate septic shock. The patient's blood pressure is stable, but they may still be at risk for further hypotension.
6. ESRD on HD: The patient has end-stage renal disease and is on hemodialysis, which may increase their risk for complications such as sepsis, candidemia, and fluid overload.
7. Hepatitis B: The patient has hepatitis B, which may increase their risk for liver-related complications such as liver failure or cirrhosis.
8. Abdominal wound: The patient has an abdominal wound that is being managed with wound vac, which may be at risk for further complications such as infection or dehiscence.
9. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient has portal venous and RIJ clots, which may increase their risk for further complications such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
10. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may increase their risk for further complications such as heart failure or cardiogenic shock.

The patient's medical team should continue to monitor their condition closely and adjust their treatment plan as needed to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, candidemia, and C. difficile colitis. She has a history of ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement with abdominal abscess requiring debridement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.3C (97.4F), HR 67 bpm, BP 110/49 mmHg, RR 27 breaths/min, SpO2 96%.
* Respiratory support: Nasal cannula with 40% FiO2, CPAP/PSV mode on ventilator.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Norepinephrine infusion at 0.05 mcg/kg/min.
* Fluid balance: Total in 1,376 mL, total out 1,376 mL, with a balance of 776 mL.
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC: 22.2 K/uL
	+ Hct: 23.0%
	+ Plt: 415 K/uL
	+ Cr: 3.6 mg/dL
	+ TCO2: 24 mmol/L
	+ Glucose: 116 mg/dL
	+ Other lab results: see note

The patient's potential medical complications are:

1. Candidemia and sepsis: The patient has a positive BCx culture with Candida albicans, and her WBC count is trending upwards without fever. This suggests that she may have disseminated fungal infection, which could lead to further complications.
2. C. difficile colitis: The patient has a history of C. difficile colitis and is currently being treated with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
3. Leukocytosis and fever: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and she has a history of fever. This could be indicative of an ongoing infection or sepsis.
4. Hypoxia: The patient is intubated and has a history of hypoxia. She is currently on CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator and is receiving oxygen therapy.
5. Altered mental status: The patient has a history of altered mental status, which could be related to her underlying infections, sepsis, or other factors.
6. Hypotension: The patient is receiving low-dose pressors and has a history of hypotension. This could be related to septic shock or other factors.
7. ESRD on HD: The patient has ESRD and is on HD. She may require further dialysis and may need to be considered for CVVH.
8. Hepatitis B: The patient has a history of HBV and is being treated with entecavir and tenofovir.
9. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has a history of autoimmune cholangiopathy and is being treated with ursodiol.
10. Abdominal wound: The patient has an abdominal wound that is being treated with a wound vac. She may require further surgical intervention.

Based on the patient's condition and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue treatment for candidemia and sepsis with micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
2. Monitor the patient's WBC count and adjust treatment as necessary.
3. Continue to provide respiratory support with CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator and oxygen therapy.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Wean the patient's pressors as tolerated and consider CVVH if necessary.
6. Continue to treat the patient's C. difficile colitis with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
7. Consider further surgical intervention for the patient's abdominal wound.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Continue to follow the patient's synthetic function tests and adjust treatment as necessary.
10. Consider further dialysis and CVVH if necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Mental
   status improved today.
   - Trial SBT again today for 30-60min to see whether can trial
   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia. She was transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status and found to have candidemia.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Candidemia/Septicemia: The patient has a history of C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole, and she is currently being treated with micafungin and additional Ambisome. The ID team is following up with her, and daily blood cultures are being taken.
2. Leukocytosis and Fever: The patient has a persistent leukocytosis, and her fevers have tapered but are still present. She is still septic and requires pressors intermittently.
3. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for airway protection, and her oxygenation has improved today. However, she is still tachypneic on PSV, and her mental status has improved.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient is still intubated for airway protection, and her acute onset of altered mental status is worrisome for a seizure. She has a history of CVA and meropenem treatment with active infection, which could contribute to seizure risk.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is suspected to be due to sepsis, and she is on very low-dose Levophed. She appears intravascularly volume overloaded, and her cortisol level is normal.
6. Abdominal Wound: The patient's wound vac was changed on Friday, and her ABD CT is unchanged. Plastic surgery is following up with her, and local care is being continued.
7. Portal Venous and RIJ Clots: The patient is on heparin gtt for these clots.
8. HepB, Autoimmune Cholangiopathy: The patient has a history of recent prednisone taper and is currently taking entecavir, tenofovir, and ursodiol. Liver function tests are being followed daily.
9. ESRD on HD: The patient's HD line was removed, and she is being sent for culture. She may need CVVH due to her pressor requirement.
10. DM: The patient is taking insulin and will be switched to Humalog SSI. Her Hct is stable, and she is being transfused for Hct>21.

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management of her multiple medical conditions. The ID team is following up with her, and daily blood cultures are being taken. The patient's family has been informed of her condition and is being updated regularly.
